acute_aquatic_toxicity.hazard_name: Hazardous to the aquatic environment Acute
acute_aquatic_toxicity.rationale: It was classified into Category 2 from 48 hours LC50=0.461mg/L(Nickel Nitrate Equivalent: 1.435mg/L) of the crustacea (Moina) (CERI/NITE Hazard Assessment Report (preliminary version), 2006).

acute_toxicity_inhalation_dust.hazard_name: Acute toxicity Inhalation: Dusts and mists

acute_toxicity_inhalation_gas.rationale: Due to the fact that the substance is "solid" according to the GHS definition and inhalation of its gas is not expected.

carcinogenicity.rationale: Due to the fact that the substance is classified as Category K (as nickel compounds) by NTP (2005) and Category 1 (as nickel compounds) by IARC (1990).

chronic_aquatic_toxicity.hazard_name: Hazardous to the aquatic environment Long-term
chronic_aquatic_toxicity.hazard_statement: Toxic to aquatic life with long lasting effects
chronic_aquatic_toxicity.rationale: Since acute toxicity was Category 2 and it was a metallic compound and an underwater action and bio-accumulation were unknown, it was classified into Category 2.

corrosive_to_metals.rationale: Test methods applicable to solid substances are not available

explosives.rationale: No data available though being nitrates, containing chemical groups with explosive properties. Classified into Division 5.1 (UN#2725) (UN Recommendations on the Transport of Dangerous Goods).

flammable_gases.hazard_name: Flammable gases including chemically unstable gases
flammable_gases.rationale: Classified as "solid" according to GHS definition

flammable_liquids.rationale: Classified as "solid" according to GHS definition

gases_under_pressure.rationale: Classified as "solid" according to GHS definition

germ_cell_mutagenicity.rationale:
Based on negative data on multi-generation mutagenicity tests (dominant lethal tests) and somatic cell mutagenicity tests in vivo (micronucleus tests), and the absence of data on germ cell mutagenicity tests in vivo, described in IARC 49 (1990), EHC 108 (1991), ECETOC 33 (1989) and ATSDR (2005).
As for the mutagenicity/genotoxicity of water-soluble inorganic nickel compounds, refer to "ID455, Nickel Chloride (II), CAS: 7718-54-9."

oxidizing_gases.rationale: Classified as "solid" according to GHS definition

oxidizing_liquids.rationale: Classified as "solid" according to GHS definition

oxidizing_solids.rationale: Inorganic compounds containing oxygen, which may cause fire when in contact with wood or paper (HSDB (2006)). Classified into Division 5.1 (UN#2725) (UN Recommendations on the Transport of Dangerous Goods).

pyrophoric_liquids.rationale: Classified as "solid" according to GHS definition

reproductive_toxicity.rationale:
Insufficient data available
As for the reproductive/developmental toxicity of water-soluble inorganic nickel compounds, refer to "D455, Nickel Chloride, CAS: 7718-54-9" and "ID453, Nickel Sulfate, CAS: 7786-81-4."

respiratory_sensitizer.hazard_statement: May cause allergy or asthma symptoms or breathing difficulties if inhaled
respiratory_sensitizer.rationale: Due to the fact that nickel compounds are classified into "Respiratory Sensitizing Substances: Group 2" according to the Recommendation on Occupational Exposure Limits for Chemical Substances (Japan Society for Occupational Health (2005)) (though not specifying nickel sulfate).

self_heating_substances.rationale: Test methods applicable to liquid substances are not available (melting point: 56.7degC (Gangolli, 2nd, 1999), test temperature: 140degC)

self_reactive_substances.rationale: No data available, though being a nitrate, containing chemical groups with explosive properties. Classified as Division 5.1 (UN#2725) (UN Recommendations on the Transport of Dangerous Goods).

skin_sensitizer.hazard_statement: May cause an allergic skin reaction
skin_sensitizer.rationale: Due to the fact that nickel compounds are classified into "Skin Sensitizing Substances: Group 1" according to the Recommendation on Occupational Exposure Limits for Chemical Substances (Japan Society for Occupational Health (2005)) (though not specifying nickel sulfate).

substances_mixtures_emit_flammable_gas_i.hazard_name: Substances and mixtures which, in contact with water, emit flammable gases

systemic_toxicity_repeat_exposure.hazard_name: Specific target organ toxicity - Repeated exposure
systemic_toxicity_repeat_exposure.rationale:
No data available
Chronic exposure to nickel and its compounds may produce respiratory irritation and degeneration in humans even at doses close to occupational exposure limits. Prolonged exposure to high concentrations is likely to result in the fibroid lung (ECETOC TR33 (1989)).

systemic_toxicity_single_exposure.hazard_name: Specific target organ toxicity - Single exposure
systemic_toxicity_single_exposure.rationale:
No data available
The acute toxicity of nickel compounds manifests in humans as "nausea, diarrhea, dizziness, headache" (ECETOC TR33 (1989)).
